column13: Worley conducts an annual materiality assessment to identify the most important sustainability issues to its business and world. Worley views these issues through the lens of the UN SDGs. The Board Health, Safety and Sustainability Committee reviews and approves Worley's material sustainability issues.
column20: Materiality assessment, sustainability issue, UN SDGs

column7: Worley's material topics are good health and wellbeing, affordable and clean energy, industry, innovation, infrastructure, and climate action.

column13: Worley was awarded the program management agreement (PMA) for the entire scope of the Woodsmith Project - a unique development comprising a mine site south of Whitby in North Yorkshire, with a 37-kilometre tunnel to transport a naturally occurring mineral, polyhalite, to processing and shipping facilities in Teesside. The mine has been designed to be sympathetic to its location in the North York Moors National Park. The number and size of buildings have been reduced to a minimum, which, together with extensive landscaping and planting, will ensure the site is screened and blends in with the surrounding area. In recognition of the area's sensitivity, mined ore will be transported underground to the materials handling facility in Teesside, ensuring that no mineral comes to the surface in the protected park.
column20: Program management agreement, Woodsmith Project, mine site

column13: Worley's Management System provides a robust framework of controls. Worley's new Scalable Engineering solution allows scaling the requirements in the Management System to match the complexity of each project. Worley's Management System is ISO 9001 certified, and compliance with this system is mandatory for all projects and operations.
column20: Management System, a framework of controls, Scalable Engineering

column13: Replic8 is Worley's robotic process automation tool to drive smart engineering solutions. Replic8 automates the mass reproduction of similar deliverables. The tool can achieve up to 60% schedule improvements and a 30% reduction in total installed cost. By reducing the time and risks from manual, repetitive tasks, customers save significant costs, allowing Worley to share in the value created and increase its competitive edge.

Worley's customer due diligence is integrated into its internal sales system. Worley expects its business partners to have ethical standards at least as high as Worley's. Worley has centralised alerts when issues are detected, and there is clear communication between its sales and due diligence teams. High-risk 'red flags' need approval in line with Worley's procedure. Worley's due diligence analysts work with the Sales team to understand the red flags and determine the appropriate mitigation strategy.
column20: Customer due diligence, internal sales system, business partner

column13: Worley supports RayGen, an Australian technology provider, in partnership with Photon Energy, an EU-listed renewable energy project developer, with their plans to build a utility-scale, grid-connected solar plant with a world-leading GWh-scale storage capacity in South Australia. The Yadnarie project is on track for state and grid connection approval. This project is the first of a growing pipeline of utility-scale projects to deliver RayGen's groundbreaking solar-plus-long-duration energy storage technology.

column13: Worley's From Ambition To Reality series, in partnership with Princeton University's Andlinger Center for Energy and the Environment, continues to build traction. The first papers, published in 2021 and 2022, considered the scale of that challenge, identifying five key shifts in infrastructure delivery needed to build at the unprecedented scale and pace required. Worley is committed to measuring and reporting how well infrastructure practitioners respond to these shifts.
column20: From Ambition to Reality, Andlinger Center for Energy and the Environment, infrastructure practitioner

column8: Indigenous, Diverse and Local Participation Plan
column13: WorleyCord works with its customers to provide meaningful engagement with Indigenous, local, and diverse communities before mobilising onto any project. This effort is guided by and aligned with Worley's Indigenous, Diverse and Local Participation Plan and customers' commitment to local communities. Worley has an extensive list of prequalified companies with Indigenous ownership or Indigenous participation via partnerships or joint ventures.
column20: Indigenous, Diverse and Local Participation Plan, Indigenous community, local community

column13: The Worley Foundation provides help to its people and communities, making a positive social and environmental impact where Worley operates. This year, Worley supports 21 organisations that its people worldwide nominated. These organisations work daily to advance STEM education, skilled volunteering and environmental and community benefits.
column20: The Worley Foundation, STEM education, community benefit

column13: The Worley Foundation undertakes thorough due diligence to keep its partnerships with organisations successful and free of ethical concerns. It involves assessing each organisation and potential risks. The Foundation also evaluate the outcomes of all funded projects. It includes examining the progress, achievements, community development and skilled volunteering.
column20: The Worley Foundation, ethical concern, due diligence

column13: In 2021, Worley announced its support for the Uluru Statement from the Heart and its call for a First Nations Voice enshrined in Australia's Constitution. After executing its 'Reflect' Reconciliation Action Plan (RAP), Worley is finalising its 'Innovate' RAP, publicly stating how it will increase First Nations engagement and participation.
column20: Reconciliation Action Plan, Uluru Statement from the Heart, First Nations Voice

column13: Worley implements the learning priorities outlined in the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) Final Report and TRC's 94 Calls to Action. A priority Worley actioned was Indigenous cultural awareness training. The training was for all Canadian staff and addressed the truth and legacy of residential schools. It is part of the healing process of reconciliation based on inclusion, mutual understanding and respect.
column20: Cultural awareness training, Truth and Reconciliation Commission, inclusion
